title: The Basics of Organic Growing Strawberries (in the Tropics)

subtasks: Confirm that the strawberries are suitable for the local climate, discussing varieties like Nabila and Flaminia.
Ensure the plants receive full sun (6-8 hours direct sunlight) and avoid overwatering in humid conditions.
Apply minimal fertilizer until flowering begins, then add vermicompost or panchagavya.
Prepare pots with drainage (6 inches deep with holes at the bottom) filled with soil mix (e.g., cocopeat, garden soil, vermicompost) leaving an inch from top.
Handle the strawberry plants carefully, avoiding burying the growing tip.
Gently remove the plant from the container by inverting and gently lifting the root ball.
Make a hole in the potting soil the size of the root ball, plant the strawberry at the same depth as in the container, and firm the soil around it.
Space two plants per pot if each is about an inch in diameter.
Cover the soil with leaf mulch to retain moisture and protect fruits.
Plant in October for January harvest; subscribe to the Green Essentials channel for more tips.
